Charleston's premier shopping destination.
address: 3000 Charleston Town Center, Charleston, WV 25389, USA

description: The West Side is a significant and historic passageway in its region. It is home to the Charleston Light Opera Guild theater company and some of the oldest and most well-known family businesses in the state. Popular places to please the palate include The Smokehouse and The Grill, a lunchtime/dinner hotspot for many state leaders and town locals. February’s Valentine Promotion includes a gift basket from Main Street retailers with prizes, such as car detailing, spa treatments, flowers and sweet treats. The Kanawha Trestle Rail Trail Project is currently working to create an urban trail for walking, biking, jogging and in-line skating in the West Side area. In June, wiener dog races are part of Charleston’s FestivALL. Included are races for puppies, adults and senior dogs, puppy parade, vet corner, food vendors, pet blessing and wiener dog merchandise.
tags: Dining & Drinks, Music, Nightlife & Entertainment, Shopping

description: Since 2007, Charlie's Harley-Davidson® has served the tri-state area with award winning sales and service of Harley-Davidson® motorcycles. Our showroom displays close to 100 new and pre-owned Harley-Davidson® motorcycles while the MotorClothes® department utilizes two floors to merchandise hundreds of clothing and gift options for all shapes, sizes and tastes. Need to give your bike come TLC? Charlie’s award winning Service Department is on deck to help out! Our shop brings over 80 years of experience that ranges from bike building, wreck reconstruction and monster horsepower builds. At Charlie’s Harley-Davidson®, we work relentlessly to be a total package dealership who values consistency as well as the integrity of our products. We treat our customers with respect and do everything in our power to take care of our customers like they are family. We are your Gold Bar & Shield dealership. Charlie's Harley-Davidson carries a full line of Harley-Davidson motorcycles, parts and accessories and MotorClothes items and collectibles. We also have a '50s-style diner which serves super-sized sandwiches and salads.

The Cheat River Lodge is a unique privately owned getaway located on the Cheat River in the Monongahela National Forest six miles east of Elkins, West Virginia. Lodging accommodations include spacious rooms in a quaint six room country inn overlooking the river and five unique cabins situated along the river. Each lodge room has a private bath and large picture window that faces the river. Each cabin is unique in structure, architecture, location, placement on the river and overall size. The cabins range from riverfront to mountain, log to stone, and historic to contemporary, but they all have a private hot tub! Whether a naturalist, adventurist, or a sightseer, there are many interesting places nearby to explore that offer year round adventure. The Cheat River and Monongahela National Forest located adjacent to the Lodge offer unlimited venues for hiking, birding, mountain biking, cross-country skiing, snow-shoeing, swimming,tubing, canoeing, kayaking, native & stocked fishing, and hunting. Rock climbing, spelunking, horseback riding, and downhill skiing are also nearby. The Cheat River Lodge is located on Old Route 33 approximately 5 miles East of Elkins, West Virginia. From the 4-lane, take the Stuart Recreation Park exit. Proceed 1 ½ mile to the green bridge, but do not cross. Turn right just before the bridge.
tags: Fishing, RV and Camping, Cabins and Vacation Rentals, Campsites

description: Located in Albright, in North Central West Virginia, the Cheat Canyon section of the Cheat River is West Virginia's premier springtime Class V whitewater run. The Canyon boasts 13 miles of unsurpassed wilderness beauty and breathtaking whitewater adventure. Not to worry, Cheat River Outfitters also offers adventures on the Class II-III Cheat Narrows. The Narrows is one of the cleanest and beautiful runs around. Enjoy fully guided whitewater rafting as well as swimming, rock jumping, rock climbing, paintball and riverside picnicking for a perfect day on the river all summer long. Plan your river trip today in West Virginia today!
address: 2764 N Preston Hwy, Albright, WV 26519, USA

company: Scholar Morgantown, Tapestry Collection by Hilton
description: Located in downtown Morgantown, this boutique hotel offers oversized guest rooms featuring top-of-the line luxury bedding, Tivoli Elegance pillow top mattresses and suites that appeal to every sense. Start the morning off right with a fresh cup of coffee, hot tea, or coco from one of the new Keurig Coffee stations conveniently located on each floor. Each station features complimentary fresh fruit, wrapped pastries, and an array of healthy breakfast bars. Other amenities include complimentary on-site garage parking and complimentary wifi. Awarded 2014 and 2015 CERTIFICATE OF EXCELLENCE Located less than 3 miles from Morgantown's Regional airport (MGW) and within steps of local businesses, theatre, shops and both WVU campuses.

Chestnut Brew Works, LLC started as a small beer brewery nestled in the woods of southern Monongalia county, about 10 miles south of Morgantown, WV in April of 2013. The demand quickly outpaced the supply, however, so we recently expanded our operations and added a taproom in the historic South Park area of Morgantown. Tap Room is open Wed. - Fri.: 4 p.m. - 11 p.m.; Sat noon - 11 p.m. We sell and fill growlers!

34 Camp Sites plus large group accommodations with advance booking. All sites have a picnic table plus a fire ring and provide a natural, private forest setting for tents, campers and RVs. No electric or water hookups. Campground facilities include a modern bath house (hot showers), rustic tent sites, firewood and ice available (at the office), large picnic shelter for groups and a tent/camping/cabin/kitchen complex available. Some sites are able to accommodate pop-up campers and trailers up to 16 ft. Office open until 11 p.m. with self registration for late arrivals. Located: North on U.S. route 19 past Fayetteville and the New River Gorge Bridge. Turn right onto Lansing Road. Go 1 ¼ mile to campground entrance on left. (PF20) Traveling South on U.S. Route 19, turn left onto Lansing Road, 5 miles south of U.S. Route 60.
tags: RV and Camping, Cabins and Vacation Rentals, Campsites

description: We are a country Bed & Breakfast in a restored 1890 farmhouse, in the heart of Pocahontas County, with 4 private guestrooms with private baths and a bungalow with private bath. While you're here, ride the Cass RR logging train to the top of the mountain, hike/bike the 78-mile Greenbrier River Trail, take a personal tour of the National Radio Telescope where they listen to outer space, bring your skis and enjoy Snowshoe Ski Resort just 15 short miles from our Inn, or just relax to our getaway and see the brightest stars you've seen in a long time while you sit by the campfire at our backyard firepit. Special events include Skiing @ Snowshoe in November, December, January, February and March, Greenbrier River Race in April, RailFan Weekend @ Cass in May, the GNCC motorsports race @ Snowshoe in June, Cass RR fiddles and viddles in July, August and September, Roadkill Cookoff in September and fall festivals and fall colors in October.
tags: Winter Sports, Dining & Drinks, Bed & Breakfasts, Hotels & Motels, Resorts

company: Chestnut Ridge Regional Park and Campground
description: Picturesque Chestnut Ridge Park & Campground is surrounded by Coopers Rock State Forest and the West Virginia University Forest, creating a total outdoor recreational area of over 12,000 acres. Open year-round, CRP offers a place to cool off in the summer with lakes for swimming, fishing, and paddle boating and a warm fire to come in to after tubing down the sled hill in the winter. At Chestnut Ridge Park & Campground you can camp, hike, bike, swim, fish, snow board or sled. Yearly events include a Toboggan Festival, Kid Fishing Rodeo, and the best Mountain Music Concert Series of the summer! Chestnut Ridge Park offers 50 wooded tent sites. We have both Single (1 tent) and Double (2 tents) pad sites, some of with have buildt up sand pads. All of the sites are front country camping and primitive, meaning no electricty. Each site includes a picnic table and fire ring. Chestnut Ridge Park has 12 back-in, water and 30 amp electric RV sites (dump station available on property).Sites are wooded, graveled and include a picnic table and fire ring.Tents are NOT permitted to be set up in the RV areas. The park is located just 10 miles east of Morgantown, WV on I-68 at exit 15 / Coopers Rock.
address: 346 Chestnut Ridge Camp Rd, Bruceton Mills, WV 26525, USA
tags: RV and Camping, Cabins and Vacation Rentals, Campsites

description: Winery/Vineyard · Wine, Beer & Spirits Store · Arts & Entertainment Chestnut Ridge Winery is located inside the Chestnut Ridge Artist Colony overlooking the City of Spencer. You can enjoy a stroll through the grounds to see the Woodworking, Jewelry Studio or the Blacksmith shop. There are also hiking and biking trails with picnic tables located near the winery. The winery also offers a large deck to sit and enjoy the views.  Open Wednesday through Saturday from 11 a.m. - 6 p.m. and Sunday 1 p.m. - 5 p.m.

Chief Logan Lodge, Hotel and Conference Center offers superior customer service, 75 modern rooms and suites, guest laundry, indoor pool, fitness room, free WiFi, and hot tub, this overnight facility is a welcome addition for travelers of US 119. Overnight guests of Chief Logan Lodge enjoy a complimentary continental breakfast from 6:30 a.m. – 9:30 a.m. daily. The Continental breakfast is included in room rental rates. The Chief Logan Conference Center offers planners a destination with all the meeting conveniences. With 20,000 square feet of meeting space and full-service restaurant. The hotel and conference center at Chief Logan is perfect for vacation, reunion, conference, or business travel. Pets are permitted in designated lodge sleeping rooms. This room type is not available as an online reservation option. Please call for pet-friendly reservations. Check-in is 4:00 p.m.; Check-out is 11:00 a.m. An early check-in option by 1:00 p.m. is available at an additional fee. One mile off US 119 at exit 30.5, this lodge and restaurant is exceptional. Visit http://www.chiefloganlodge.com/ for special rates and packages, events, hours and more.
address: 1000 Conference Center Dr, Logan, WV 25601, USA
tags: Dining & Drinks, Cabins and Vacation Rentals, Hotels & Motels, Resorts

description: Located four miles north of Logan in the heart of West Virginia’s southern coalfields, Chief Logan State Park is one of the most visited facilities in the West Virginia State Parks System. The park is also located within close proximity to the Hatfield-McCoy ATV trails for campers looking for a uniquely West Virginia adventure. Chief Logan State Park is all about recreation. The campground offers 26 units, 14 of which have full water, sewage and electric hookups, 12 have electric and water only. Hot showers are available at a centrally located bathhouse. The campground also features a water slide at the swimming pool and an outdoor amphitheater (seasonal by nature), Museum in the Park, hiking trails, multiple picnic shelters, fishing and more, makes this state park a favorite destination for daytime activity or overnight camping. Campsites may be reserved anytime online, by phone, or at the campground office.
address: 1000 Conference Center Dr, Logan, WV 25601, USA
tags: ATV & Off-roading, Fishing, Hiking, RV and Camping, History & Heritage, Music, Campsites

description: Where Soccer meets Golf in the beautiful mountains of Tucker County West Virginia! We are a small 9 hole Footgolf links. Loads of fun! Come try it out! FootGolf is a combination of soccer and golf. The game is played with a soccer ball. The rules largely correspond to the rules of golf. The player with the fewest kicks wins. Chips Shots is a dedicated FootGolf course. FootGolf can be played individually and in groups. A group of 4 is ideal. Chips Shots was created out of a small family farm. Enjoy the game and great views.
address: 16320 Dry Fork Rd, Davis, WV 26260, USA

description: The dream of establishing Chirico’s Italian Ristorante’ was begun in 1981 by the owner and founder Frank Ray Chirico. Frank passed along to his three sons his love of preparing old world Italian dishes. Today, you will enjoy the very same flavors made from the recipes passed down from generations when you visit Chirico’s.

Beckley's local coffee shop, featuring fresh blends roasted onsite. 100% fruit smoothies and hand-dipped Hershey's ice cream, as well. Plenty of room inside and out to relax or work or visit with friends and family as you enjoy a treat from the Chocolate Moose. We're also the home of Mountain State Miniature Golf and the Outside-In Climbing Gym. You could stay here for awhile!

Christopher's Eats provides an inviting and relaxing atmosphere with great food and awesome scratch cocktails, craft beers, and more for family and friends to enjoy. Christopher's is known for fresh from scratch food, burgers, seafood, steaks from our butcher shop next door, wings, and coal fired flatbreads in the state's only 100% coal burning oven.

CMC features a 950 seat theatre with year-round national touring productions of theatre, musicals, live concerts, comedy and more. The facilities are available for rent, with space for 10 to 1000 guests.

City government organization in Dunbar. The City of Dunbar would like to invite everyone to visit our city. We are located between Charleston and Nitro along the Midland Trail. We believe you will enjoy our community whether you anchor your boat on the Kanawha River at Dunbar Landing to picnic or fish, or travel by car to visit one of our parks (Wine Cellar Park, Laura Anderson Lake, Shawnee Regional Park). Please plan on attending one of our many events held throughout the year.

City Government Office/Public Service Office. Moundsville is a small town nestled in the northern panhandle of scenic West Virginia. Moundsville is a growing family based community rich in heritage and history. Deriving its name from the many Adena Indian burial mounds constructed more than 2000 years ago. Moundsville is home to the largest conical burial mound in North America. Moundsville is not only a land of sacred pasts, but of promising futures. Moundsville, WV is a melting pot of fine education, a strong blue-collar workforce, bountiful heritage and beautiful landscapes.

If you like the arts, Princeton is the place to visit. Colorful murals on Mercer Street create a vibrant downtown area. New attractions and shops make up a lot of the downtown revitalization. One of these attractions is the Princeton Railroad Museum, which features exhibits, artifacts and more. You can catch a show or performance later in the evening at the Chuck Mathena Center. As for history, Civil War buffs will want to visit the McNutt House, the first stop on the Civil War Trail.

We are the only FULL service hotel in Fairmont. We offer rooms for events, along with catering, food and beverages, providing all the essentials you’re searching for when you get together. Corporate travelers will appreciate our business center, as well as copy, print and fax machines. You can order room service or grab a bite to eat at the hotel’s restaurant and bar. You're always a VIP here which is why we offer such additional amenities as: Free breakfast Free WiFi Seasonal outdoor pool Fitness center Free weekday newspaper Our hotels provide you with personalized service, all the amenities you need, and a dash of fun to make every trip enjoyable. Each guest room offers a refrigerator, microwave, hair dryer and TV. Select rooms include sofa sleepers, and guests receive free coffee in the lobby. The Clarion Inn hotel in Fairmont, West Virginia is conveniently located near Morgantown, Clarksburg and Bridgeport. Fairmont State University and West Virginia University are minutes away. Our pet-friendly hotel in Fairmont is also located near these points of interest: Valley Worlds of Fun Valley Falls State Park Heston Farm Winery Fairmont General Hospital Marion County Historical Society Museu
address: 930 E Grafton Rd, Fairmont, WV 26554, USA

description: The beautiful surroundings of Beckley are at your fingertips when you stay at the conveniently located Clarion Pointe® Beckley hotel. Whitewater rafting on the New River is only 15 minutes away. Enjoy over 10,000 acres of ATV trails at Burning Rock Off-Road Park only 10 minutes away. If that's not enough access, the Hatfield-McCoy trail systems are only 30 minutes away. You'll get to experience over 700 miles of fun on your ATV in the mountains of southern West Virginia.
address: 300 Harper Park Dr, Beckley, WV 25801, USA

description: The Clarksburg History Museum was founded in 2017 by a small group of dedicated volunteers. We opened our doors on November 11, 2018 as part of Clarksburg's Veterans' Day celebration. Our first exhibits honored our local veterans. We have been growing and expanding our offerings ever since. We are passionate about educating our community and passing on an appreciation for our art, history, and culture. Our goal is to ensure that visiting the Clarksburg History Museum is an enriching, exciting, and educational experience. Special events are held on a regular basis and school field trips were instituted in the fall of 2019.
address: 445 W Main St #251, Clarksburg, WV 26301, USA

description: Classic Plastics Toy Store is a local vintage (mainly 70s-90s) & new toy store/arcade dealing in toys, video games, comic books, arcade machines and more! Classic Plastics is always searching for new inventory and arcade machines to offer. Features currently held licenses from modern toy companies like Funko, NECA, Mezco, Super7, and Moose Toys. If you are looking for something specific or wanting to sell your collection, give Classic Plastics a call!
address: 404 Fort Harmar Dr, Marietta, OH 45750, USA

company: Classic's 3 Hot Spot Lounge and Restaurant
description: CLASSICS 3 is a street-level family diner with great food, char-grill burgers, wings and more. We offer a freshly-prepared full menu for breakfast, lunch and dinner. We have a great menu plus serving breakfast all day long as well as our delicious sandwiches, hoagies, soup and salads. Try our Spaghetti and meatballs,sausage or chicken ,served with salad and garlic bread or parmesan bread,(your choice) We also offer Flavor Burst Ice Cream in eight great flavors. Children’s cones start at 50 cents. Call ahead for eat-in or carry-out. Enjoy our upstairs bar (M-Sat. @ 11am) with pool tables, HDTV and jukebox. Play all WV Lottery games here. We have plenty of parking. All major credit cards accepted.
address: CLASSICS, 1384 Green Bag Road, Morgantown, WV 26508, USA

description: Invest time in the town of Bramwell and visit this museum that houses relics and exhibits of West Virginia's coal history. You will find photos of former Bramwell coal barons, their wives, memorabilia of the millionaire days and much more.

company: Coal River Kayak and Canoe Rental
description: Coal River Kayak & Canoe Rental is based in the Coal River Watershed that includes the Coal River, Big Coal River and Little Coal river that are within the Walhonde Water trail. These streams are flat water streams with class 1 rapids that are very safe for family float trips. The float trips are great for fishing, wildlife viewing, beginners and just a relaxing day on the river. The rental center is located in the CRG River Center which is located in Meadowood Park at Upper Falls of the Coal River in Tornado, WV. All trips originate at the River Center and includes several 6 to 7 mile options, plus one 12-mile adventure trip. Many options are available for specialty trips, overnights, catering, and student paddle lessons. The group operates a rental and shuttle service too. Season begins in mid-April and extends through September of each year. Credit cards, cash and checks are accepted. Advance reservations are recommended.
address: 181 Pettigrew Ln, St Albans, WV 25177, USA

description: Cody's is a kitchen and cocktails restaurant that take prides in the quality of the ingredients used for each and every dish. Cody's sources fresh, local ingredients to create the signature entrees that make up our menu. You'll also find unique, seasonal items; created especially for your enjoyment. A cozy atmosphere, relaxed bar, dinner service, pub-style lunch and Sunday brunch will delight the foodie in each of you.

When you visit us you will see that our mission is to provide you with superior products and service. To build quality relationships with you and others is what we strive for, whether it be out on the road or in the store. Cole Harley-Davidson® is a family-owned dealership that fosters an environment which makes it easy for you to do business,

The Colonial Motel has twenty-two rooms situated on a large three acre lot adjacent to the Guyandotte River in Man, WV. The Colonial Restaurant in the Motel complex, for your convenience, offers home cooked meals from 5:30 A.M. until 9:00 P.M. daily. The Convenience Store, also on the Motel grounds is open from 8:00 A.M. until 11:00 P.M. daily to supply all those little extras you need when away from home. Hatfield McCoy trail rider permits are available in the convenience store. The Colonial Motel is less than one half mile from the Hatfield McCoy Rockhouse Trail Head. Our large parking lot will accommodate trucks and ATV trailers. In addition to the Hatfield McCoy trails, within a short drive are additional recreation facilities for your entertainment. These include: Chief Logan State Park and the Larry Joe Harless Center, with exercise facilities as well as a large indoor pool and movie theaters.

company: Comfort Inn Barboursville near Huntington Mall area
description: The Comfort Inn hotel in Barboursville, West Virginia is located off of Interstate 64 and near the Huntington Mall. It is near Blenko Glass Company, Marshall University, Huntington Junior College and Camden Park. Enjoy free WiFi, complimentary breakfast every morning, an on-site fitness center and free weekday newspaper. Each room comes fully equipped with 32-inch flat-screen TVs and irons, while the suites include microwaves and refrigerators. Comfort Inn will ensure your stay is a success!

Our hotel is nestled along the Coal River in the heart of the Appalachian Mountains. Spend the day at the 9,300-acre Kanawha State Forest, which offers an impressive network of hiking and biking trails, as well as picturesque picnic areas and beautiful wildlife. Off-roading enthusiasts will want to hit the popular Hatfield-McCoy Trails in Williamson. You can also head north to Charleston to visit the State Capitol, West Virginia State Museum, and Coonskin Park. During the summer months, cool down with the slides and lazy river at Water Ways water park. Get energized for the day ahead with a workout in the fitness center and use free WiFi to scope out the area—or ask our friendly front desk staff for recommendations. Ricky and Sam Harper embarked on this journey in order to provide more people with the chance to eat a natural sweetener; pure maple syrup! description: Located in Glady, WV (Randolph County), we are experienced outdoorsmen offering a wilderness, backcountry fishing experience on Shavers Fork in the Allegheny Mountains of West Virginia. Shavers Fork is one of the five forks that makes up the Cheat River and has been ranked as one of the top ten cleanest rivers in the United States, boasting some of the best trout fishing available. Our experienced guides will take care of you every step of the way. The horseback ride from the trailhead is roughly 3.5 hours into our base camp. Our horses, packers, and guides will ensure you have a safe and enjoyable ride into your camp. Excursions are two nights and three days, where your days will be filled with trout fishing followed by excellent meals by the campfire. You will enjoy a peaceful night’s sleep in the quiet of the Monongahela National Forest at a camp we have set up and ready for you.

The Rhododendron Campground has 25 primitive tent/hammock campsites, each with their own picnic table and fire pit. description: Bed and Breakfast & Pick Your Own Strawberry Farm A family friendly, West Virginia Bed and Breakfast near Elk River kayaking, fishing, swimming, ATV and bike trails. Near Charleston, WV (25 min) but located on a country road in Clendenin, WV. Families, couples and solo travelers can enjoy hiking the numerous trails with beautiful views on the 91 acre property.Guests can visit the farm animals, fishing pond, future peach orchard, catch minnows in the creek, peruse the berry field, and enjoy a campfire at night and star gaze. Guests may want to explore the scenic back road through Clay County that passes the home of the Golden Delicious Apple. The road continues to Gauley Bridge, Hawks Nest, Fayetteville, and the New River Gorge National Park for white water rafting, hiking, and exploring. Book your stay and come experience the hospitality and West Virginia history that Country Road House and Berries Bed and Breakfast has to offer. Homemade breakfast is included each morning with this reservation and all dietary restrictions are considered. Strawberry picking is available each May for guests when in season. Enjoy nearby Elk River Swimming, Bike, ATV Trails, and Flat water Class I rapid Kayaking. Voted One of the Top 11 Unique Place to Stay in West Virginia for 2022!

description: Cox Camping is located on 60 acres of wooded land. Over 35 camp sites available for RV or tent camping. We have hiking trails, fishing pond, children's playground, horseshoes, etc. Check our directional map on our web site. Our Main Lodge includes a Pool & Game Room, Camp Store with Antique Shop, Soda Machine, Large Viewing Deck, Wedding - Event Pavilion and much more. The lounge area is A/C controlled and has TWO 50” Satellite TVs and another TV on the outside deck for your viewing enjoyment. Our new and improved Free WiFi which is widely available, but not at all sites. We have hot showers, flush toilets and a laundry room available 24 hours a day. Other amenities include: two bedroom cottage is available for $85 per night and includes full kitchen with refrigerator, electric range, microwave, washer and dryer, bathroom w/shower, central A/C, picnic table and a large swing; and a 16 ft. camper trailer with heat and air conditioning $30.00 per night. Our dump station, showers, laundry room, flush toilets and hot showers are always open. Check in time is optional with prior arrangements. Check out time is 1 p.m. Cash, checks or money orders accepted. We will accept credit cards in the near future. PAY 6 NIGHTS AND 7TH IS FREE! BRING YOUR OWN LINENS, PILLOWS,SLEEPING BAGS ETC.

description: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, The Craik – Patton House is a splendid example of Greek Revival architecture in the Kanawha River Valley of West Virginia. Constructed in 1834, the Craik- Patton House or “Elm Grove” as it was known then, was built downtown Charleston, Virginia, now West Virginia, by James Craik, grandson of Dr. James Craik close friend and personal physician to President George Washington. Later, the home was purchased by Confederate Colonel George S. Patton I, grandfather of WW2 General George S. Patton. It was moved twice but ultimately was saved by the National Society of Colonial Dames in America in the State of West Virginia (NSCDAWV) and moved in 1973 to its current location. Tours of the Craik – Patton House are free to the public. Donations to support the museum are welcome! Closed major holidays. We suggest calling ahead before visiting as staff schedules, weather, and other appointments could alter open times. We are behind the Charleston Moose Lodge and before the Boy Scouts Building and Daniel Boone Park.
address: 2809 Kanawha Blvd E, Charleston, WV 25311, USA

description: Cranberry Campground features 28 single campsites and two double sites in two loops. Most sites can accommodate a 40' trailer. Each site has a picnic table, fire ring, lantern post and gravel parking spur. There are two handpumps and four accessible vault toilets. There is no electricity available but the use of generators is permitted from 6am until 10pm. No dump station is available at campground. There are two privately owned dump stations available in Richwood, WV. Maximum length of stay is 14 days. Check-out time is 2:00 p.m. Dogs are permitted if on a leash at all times. Leash must be 6 ft. or shorter. Food storage order applies to pet food also. Located on Forest Road 76, 13.5 miles from Richwood, West Virginia, and 7 miles from Dyer, West Virginia. More information on this campground is available through the Gauley Ranger District, 932 North Fork Cherry Rd., Richwood, WV 26261 (304) 846-2695.

Cranberry Creek Cascades is a natural treasure in the downtown Beckley area. To access the falls, take Stanaford Mine Road in Beckley and drive a quarter-mile to enter onto the Piney Creek Preserve entrance. Wildwood Trailhead and Waterfall Hollow Trail are on the right. Take the stone steps and make your way onto the Waterfall Hollow Trail. This trail is a former coal mine bench – making the 100-yard walk relatively flat. You will be greeted by two separate waterfalls at the Little Whitestick Creek and Cranberry Creek confluence: Cranberry Creek Cascades on the right, and Little Whitestick Falls to the left. Your walk is almost completed when you hear the relaxing sound of layering cascades gushing over the slippery rocks of Cranberry Creek.
address: 151 Stanaford Mine Rd, Beckley, WV 25801, USA

Curtisville Lake offers 695 acres of lush scenery. Around the 30-acre lake there are hiking trails and picnicking. An ADA accessible fishing pier has been added to the lake. The lake is periodically stocked by the Department of Natural Resources and the fishing is good. Activities include: non-motorized boating, hiking, biking, fishing, and leisure activities. Home of the Annual Family Fun Fishing Day each Spring on Good Friday. No swimming is permitted in the lake. No gasoline powered motors are allowed, only electric motors and oars are permissible to power a boat in the lake. There are five RV sites and six primitive sites available on a first come, first served basis. Camping is permitted from April 1 through October 31 each year. Check-in is at 1:00 PM and check-out is at 11:00 AM. Pets are allowed if they are on a leash and under control at all times. Pets must be cleaned up after and pet waste should be disposed of at pet stations. Pets are not allowed in the restrooms or playground area. RV Site: $20.00/night/Each site includes electric, fire ring and picnic area. (Pay on-site) Primitive Site: $10.00/night/Each site includes fire ring, picnic area and lantern post. (Pay on-site) Picnic Area Regulations: Picnic areas (other than the pavilion) are on a first come, first serve basis. Portable grills are permitted and must be used responsibly. Please leave the picnic area as you found it, clean and free of trash. Directions to Curtisville Lake: From Fairmont: Take Route 250 North out of Fairmont towards Mannington. When you reach the Town of Mannington, take a left on Main Street, (there are brown signs for Curtisville Lake). Main St. turns into Rt. 1 and passes the Mannington Fair grounds. Stay on Rt. 1 for about 5 miles just past Logansport. Take a left on Curtisville Pike (Rt.7). Go about a mile and the lake is on the left.
tags: Biking, Fishing, Hiking, RV and Camping, Watersports, Campsites, Public Waters

Dr. Robert McNutt House is located at 1522 North Walker Street, Princeton, WV. It is the only house left standing in Princeton after the town was burned during the Civil War. The House is on the National Register of Historic Places. The McNutt House was used as headquarters during the war for Lt. Col. Rutherford B. Hayes and Sgt. William McKinley (both past U. S. Presidents). The McNutt House was also used as a hospital during May 1862. Located along the West Virginia Civil War Trail. Hours: Monday-Friday 9-4. No admission charge. Visitors welcome.

company: Eckhart House Tea Room, Tours and Gift Shoppe
description: The Eckhart House is an 1892 Queen Anne Town Home located in Victorian Old Town which is the N. Wheeling Historic District. The Tea Room - elegant Teas are served in the dining room on Saturdays, May through December. Reservations are required. Home Tours - Guided Tours of the home's living quarters are offered May through December on Fridays and Saturdays. 1 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. Teas and Tours are available by appointment for groups of 6 or more or for a minimum charge. Built in 1892 by wealthy banker George W. Eckhart Jr., the Eckhart House was considered by the Wheeling Daily Intelligencer of October 29, 1892 to be one of the residential building achievements of the year. With most of its original architectural features well preserved, it is truly deserving of the title Victorian Wheeling’s ‘Crown Jewel’. The three story Queen Anne town home is nestled in the heart of Victorian Old Town and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Eckhart House offers a Tea Room, a Gift Shop and is also available for touring.

description: We hope you'll enjoy the very casual atmosphere of The Front Porch...the food...the view! On a clear day you can have a fantastic view of Seneca Rocks and the surrounding Allegheny Mountains. The Front Porch Restaurant is located in Harper's Old General Store. HOURS: The Front Porch is OPEN (Except in the Winter) Saturday 11 a.m. to 10 p.m. Sunday - Friday 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. Harper's Old country Store is one of the oldest continuously operated businesses in West Virginia. The Old Store was built in 1902 and has been operated under the name of "D. C. Harper and Co., a general country store", serving generations. The business, situated in front of the majestic and scenic Seneca Rocks, continues to be operated by the Harper family. The interior of the store is much the same as in 1902 with many old features and antiques. The original board floor that must be oiled frequently, the antique, metal, blocked ceiling, the original shelving and counters, and numerous antiques and memorabilia give the visitor the feeling of stepping back in time. The architecture of the building along with the big front porch represents the vintage of middle and late 1800s. The Store is an antique and be truly an educational experience.
address: PO Box 9, Seneca Rocks, WV 26884, USA

description: Stay in a rustic yurt nestled in the Allegheny Mountains and overlooking stunning Germany Valley. Located near any local outdoor recreational attractions: Spruce Knob, Nelson Rocks, Seneca Rocks, and Seneca Caverns to name a few. Located 15 minutes from the township of Franklin with a rich history and culture, known especially for its many Victorian style houses. This structure is a semi-permanent residential yurt. It is designed to be highly energy-efficient and is insulated with SIP panels to keep it toasty in colder months. Space heaters, cookware, and utensils are provided. The building (sleeps 4) consists of 1 bedroom with a queen-size bed, bathroom with a standing shower, kitchen area, and sitting area with a double size foldout futon. You will need to provide your own linens. The yurt is located on the grounds of Future Generations University global campus. description: One of the few plantations left in the state is Henderson Hall in Williamstown. Built in 1836 overlooking the Ohio River, this three-story, 29-room Italianate mansion was the focal point of social and political life for almost two centuries. Period pieces are still intact and include a rosewood piano, the original wood floors, a collection of rare clocks, and a 12-foot gilt mirror, with 17th Century furnishings and portraits still in place. Hours: OPEN MARCH - DECEMBER CLOSED MONDAYS 12:00PM—5:00 PM

company: Gandy Dancer Theatre and Conference Center
description: Enjoy West Virginia's ONLY Branson-style dinner shows. The Gandy Dancer Theatre features two full length dinner shows back to back. Our Premier Dinner Show has music from the 40's - present day of country, rock n' roll, gospel, Motown, patriotic and so much more. Dinner consists of lemon peppered chicken and pot roast, carrots and potatoes served with macaroni salad, dinner roll, cake and beverage. Our Tribute to Musical Legends Dinner Show features all the artists you love with comedy and amazing artists. Dinner consists of chicken cordon bleu, hamburger steak with gravy, baked potato, green beans, coleslaw, dinner roll, cake and beverage. Specialty shows throughout the year include Murder Mystery Dinner Shows, Aloha with Elvis Dinner Shows, A Mountain Memories Christmas Dinners, Christmas with Elvis and a Rockin' New Year's Eve Oldies Dinner Dance Show.

company: Gauley River Wild & Woolly Primitive Campground
description: NOT YOUR RUN OF THE MILL CAMPGROUND! What says agritourism more than a campground on a small-scale wool sheep farm located in the Gauley River National Recreation Area? The Tawney Farm offers a unique alternative to the overcrowded commercial campgrounds with farm camping at Gauley River Wild & Woolly Primitive Campground. Here you’re only a short drive from the New River Gorge National Park and Summersville Lake, and within walking distance of the Gauley River with all it’s wild untamed beauty where you can swim, kayak, paddleboard, or splash in a waterfall. And you get to camp on a sheep farm, where you have the opportunity to learn about wool and wool processing. You can even learn how to felt wool and take your creation home! Enjoy peaceful and private, safe and secure camping on our farm. While The Gauley River Wild & Woolly Primitive Campground might have "primitive" in the name, don't let that fool you. From March through Labor Day and November, we provide a total of 8 sites on our farm for camping with a site suited for every camping style! Three sites in our main field accommodate both campers and small RVs (up to 35') as well as tent and vehicle camping. Three sites are tent and vehicle camping only and two are tent only, one with a 3-minute hike and one with a 20-minute hike to the top of the mountain for incredible night skies! All sites are spaciously separate from one another where you'll feel you're the only campers here. ​And there are plenty of amenities! Park-style and fire pit grills, tables, water, hot water shower, clean portajohns and a dishwashing station. Perfect for couples who want to get away from it all, or for families or groups of friends with different camping styles who want to reconnect and catch up. During the Gauley whitewater season (the day after Labor Day through the third weekend in October), we switch to festival-style camping to welcome hundreds of rafters and kayakers from across the country to camp for the Gauley River whitewater season. Try an alternative to commercial campgrounds and make your reservation today!
tags: RV and Camping, Cabins and Vacation Rentals, Campsites, Public Waters

The Great Eastern Trail ("GET") is an 1800-mile footpath through the Appalachians, linking Alabama to New York. Entering West Virginia at Matewan, the trail hits many of the state's most beautiful parks and picturesque towns before entering Virginia near Narrows. Whether you're interested in an hour-long stroll or a week long adventure, the GET has something for you. For completed sections and to get involved, please contact TuGuNu Hiking Club.

description: The Greenbrier River Trail is a 78-mile former railroad now used for hiking, biking and horseback riding. It is the longest trail of its kind in West Virginia. The trail provides many breathtaking views as it passes through several small towns, crosses 35 bridges, goes through two tunnels and cuts through some of West Virginia’s most remote areas. The Greenbrier River Trail is one of 50 Millennium Legacy Trails in the United States, and was rated one of the top 10 hiking trails in the country by Backpacker Magazine. Part of the Greenbrier River Trail lies within a National Radio Quiet Zone so cell phones do not work. The trail begins at Caldwell, WV near Greenbrier State Forest and passes through numerous small towns and traverses 35 bridges and 2 tunnels as it winds its way along the valley with its northern terminus at Cass Scenic Railroad State Park in Pocahontas County. Throughout much of its length, the trail is adjacent to the Greenbrier River and is flanked by peaks of the Allegheny Mountains. The surface is generally hard packed, but varies from rough to fine gravel. Several state parks and forests along the Greenbrier River Trail provide overnight accommodations. These locations include Greenbrier State Forest, Watoga State Park, Seneca State Forest and Cass Scenic Railroad.
address: 4800 Watoga Park Rd, Marlinton, WV 24954, USA

description: Located in the southeastern corner of the state near the border of Virginia, Greenbrier State Forest provides over 5,100 acres of heavily forested, mountainous terrain for outdoor recreation. Magnificent views of the surrounding countryside are afforded by the impressive and imposing 3,280' high Kate's Mountain. The park offers a 16-unit campground suitable for tents and trailers. The sites feature electric hookups, picnic table, on-site and central bathhouse, and a stone fireplace for grilling-out with the family. The campground is open spring through fall, weather permitting. Campsites may be reserved online at any time, by phone or at the campground office. Greenbrier State Forest has 14 cabins where you can kick back and enjoy your mountain retreat to the beautiful southeastern corner of West Virginia. These cabins have plenty of room for the whole family and the forest provides acres upon acres of rugged woodland for adventure. Designated pet-friendly cabins are available. Cabins are available April-October. Check in begins at 4 p.m., and check out is by 10 a.m. for all cabins.
address: 1541 Harts Run Rd, Caldwell, WV 24925, USA

description: A visit to this quaint, historic community, at the confluence of the Potomac and Shenandoah rivers, is like stepping into the past. The charming town of Harpers Ferry is known for its rich history and scenic beauty. Step back in time and stroll the parks picturesque streets, visit exhibits and museums and hike the trails and battlefields. Discover the scenic and historic C&O Canal or for a more challenging climb hike the Appalachian Trail for stunning views of the Blue Ridge Mountains and Potomac and Shenandoah river valleys. Endless adventures await in Harpers Ferry including whitewater rafting class-III rapids or simply visiting the towns lovely shops and incredible restaurants.

We offer 20, 30 and 50amp electric sites. Some sites have a concrete patio and fire ring. Our camping sites are pet friendly. Our handicapped accessible bathhouse features 3 separate rooms for privacy with sink, commode and shower. Our rustic riverfront cabins are equipped with heat, AC and full bathrooms.

We offer both RV and tent camping, Camping Cabins, Deluxe Cabins and a group bunkhouse that can accommodate up to 20 people. 50 max amp, RV and Tent Camping, Camping Cabins, Deluxe Cabins, group bunkhouse, cable tv, propane, pavilion, 65' max length, pool, mini golf, bike rentals, wifi, snack bar, firewood, dog park, laundry facilities, indoor and outdoor basketball, junior olympic pool, arcade game room, and much more. Open year-round.

description: Find yourself at the confluence of history and nature. Experience a flash point that ignited the Civil War. Find your story in the struggle for freedom, education, and civil rights. Explore the rolling Blue Ridge mountains and rushing waters of the Shenandoah and Potomac rivers. Stroll the picturesque streets, visit exhibits and museums, or hike our trails and battlefields. Spend a day or a weekend. Discover your Harpers Ferry. Harpers Ferry National Historical Park offers a wide variety of activities for individuals and families. Explore museums and exhibits, hike to overlooks or along Civil War skirmish lines, join a ranger-guided tour or sign-up for a living history workshop. Shop at the Harpers Ferry Park Association's Bookshop for books, artwork, postcards, and items for kids of all ages. Talk to rangers and volunteers at the Visitor Center and Information Center who will assist you and answer any questions you may have. NOTE: some visitor services, park spaces, and events may be impacted by current COVID-19 safety restrictions. Please visit the park website for the most up-to-date information.
address: 171 Shoreline Dr, Harpers Ferry, WV 25425, USA
tags: Biking, Hiking, History & Heritage, National Parks

description: Experience the legendary families of the feud by visiting the Hatfield Homeplace, just a half-mile away from the National Landmarked Hatfield Cemetery – where all feuding family lay at rest. You may even meet direct family descendants and experience how the legendary Hatfield family patriarch lived during and after the feud. The last homeplace and hideout of the feud patriarch “Devil Anse” Hatfield boasts an on-site Hatfield McCoy Museum showcasing actual relics from the feud and families. Just crossing the bridge built by “Devil Anse” himself, you are walking on feud history! Not to mention the family’s moonshine well from when they made their own corn liquor. This site also features a gift shop that prides itself on carrying unique local artisan souvenirs and authentic Hatfield McCoy merchandise. The Hatfield Homeplace also hosts its own food truck, “Eat’n with The Hatfield’s” that serves hot and fresh delicious meals to enjoy on the serene property.
address: 12790 Jerry W Hwy, Sarah Ann, WV 25644, USA

company: Hatfield and McCoy ATV Trail - Pocahontas Trail
description: The Hatfield McCoy trails offer more than 800 miles of off-road adventure as they wind through these southern mountains. It all begins with Mercer County’s Pocahontas trailhead in historic Bramwell. This convenient access point to 1-77 has a spacious parking lot and rest area. Best of all, it’s open year round. The Pocahontas Tailhead is the Southern Gateway to the Hatfield McCoy Trail system.

Known for its adrenaline-pumping excitement, the Hatfield-McCoy Trails guarantee endless adventures around every twist and turn. Spanning across southern West Virginia, the Trails boast over 1,000 miles broken up by 10 systems. There are trails for beginners and experts alike. This spring, take to the mountains of West Virginia for an adventure like no other. wp:heading {"textAlign":"center"} [if lt IE 9]><script>document.createElement('video');</script><![endif] https://wvtourism.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/03.11.24-Hatfield-McCoy-Listing-Video-Compressed.mp4 /wp:paragraph /wp:genesis-blocks/gb-column /wp:genesis-blocks/gb-columns

description: Nestled in the heart of whitewater rafting country, Hawks Nest State Park encompasses 276 acres bordering a rugged section of the New River Gorge National River. Long known for its panoramic views, the park offers a 31-room lodge for the comfort of overnight guests, on-site restaurant and an aerial tramway (seasonal). Below the lodge, the New River forms peaceful Hawks Nest Lake. Above the lake, the narrow canyon and rushing water create one of the most challenging whitewater boating waterways in the nation. The lodge and restaurant is open year-round. Online reservations are available. Park map, hours of operation and special rates are maintained on the state park website.
address: 49 Hawks Nest Rd, Ansted, WV 25812, USA

company: Healthberry Farm and Honey River Meadery
description: Healthberry Farm is a small family farm producing honey, honey wine and beeswax products. At Healthberry Farm, we believe in the importance of working with nature to produce the finest products possible. Our varietal honeys are raw and come to you straight from the hive, without pasteurization or processing. Honey River meads are aged for two years so they can be bottled without sulfites. Our salves and candles are made with simple ingredients that are good for your body and the air you breathe. We do not add any chemicals, preservatives, colors or additives to any of our products, as they are unnecessary and often harmful. Healthberry bees forage on plants in a wild setting, a safe distance from sources of toxic contamination, and are never moved for pollination services. Our practices give you an opportunity to support eco-friendly, small-scale farming while treating yourself to delicious varietal honey products made by healthy, happy bees. Farm Tours available by appointment only. Please call with 24+ hours notice for the best chances of catching us.

9 sites available year-round, water electric and sewer, cable & phone available for monthly up renters- camping season: year-round $30 night or $600 monthly camping season: year-round 5 miles from Weston off I-79 exit 99 to Route 33 east. Turn on Berlin Road off Route 33, located between Wal-Mart and Sheetz. Approximately 3 miles on the right at the top of the hill (at the 18 mail boxes).

Hemlock Haven Luxury Cabins offers 6 exceptional lodging options. Four cabins have 3 bedrooms and 2 full baths which can sleep 8 guests. One cabin (Bingo’s Bungalow) is larger and has a game room with foosball, pool, air hockey and darts. Bingo’s Bungalow can sleep 12 guests. Newly finished in 2017 is Serenity Lodge. This property has 14 private acres and boasts 5 bedrooms, 3 full baths, a recreation room, a bar and a fishing pond. The lodge can sleep 18 guests. All properties Dog Friendly.

Built in 1859 as the centerpiece of the 2,600 acre Henderson plantation, this impressive 20-room pre Civil War mansion with all its original furnishings, has survived as a legacy of the Victorian and Edwardian eras.

Heritage Farm Museum & Village is a recreated 19th century Appalachian village that includes museums, animal exhibits, artisans, and an adventure park. Experience life for the region’s settlers from the 1850s onward, interact with animals in the petting zoo and nature center, see talented artisans work, and embrace adventure on the ziplines, high ropes courses, and mountain bike park. Our friendly staff and museum guides are ready at every turn to help create a memorable day for guests of all ages.

Built in 1841, The Hermitage, is one of the oldest properties in Petersburg, West Virginia. It was converted into a hotel in 1881 and has been in operation ever since. Today, the hotel begins a new chapter as The Hermitage Inn and Taphouse, though details of its rich past have been lovingly preserved. From our welcoming and inviting communal spaces, to our stylish yet comfortable guest rooms, the new look and atmosphere of the hotel draws inspiration from the mountainous landscape surrounding it.

Hidden Trails Stables is located in Lost River State Park, Mathias, WV. We offer guided trail rides on horseback from April through October. Calm, gentle horses, friendly guides. Reservations accepted, but walk-ins are welcome. See our website for hours. We accept cash, check or credit cards.
address: 6849 Dove Hollow Rd, Mathias, WV 26812, USA

description: Short term rental vacation properties in the beautiful state of WV!
First class log vacation cabin rentals

We have 3 log cabins, 2 cottages and a 28' camper ready to rent. In addition, we have 7 RV spots with 50 amp hook ups, water, sewage, WiFi and a bathhouse for your convenience. We are located one mile from Devil Anse Trails that run into either Buffalo Mountain Trail or Rockhouse Trails. You can hit the trails right from our campground!! We also have Hatfield-McCoy Trail permits, snacks, drinks, ice and souvenirs at our store.

These spacious rooms also offer work desks, free local calls and flat panel TVs with HBO for your enjoyment. Also, take advantage of our complimentary hot breakfast bar, which can be taken to-go for your convenience. Check out our great Weston hotel deals, and start planning your trip today.

Our complimentary Express Start hot breakfast features goodies, such as warm cinnamon rolls, eggs, bacon, fruit, yogurt, cereals and coffee. The hotel offers our guests amenities such as meeting & event space, Undo’s Italian Restaurant & The Sports Bar along with a seasonal outdoor pool. Located next to the hotel you will enjoy multiple restaurants, retail and grocery stores. This Weirton-Steubenville Area hotel is the premier hotel for guests visiting Steubenville OH & Franciscan University of Steubenville. The hotel is located off US RT 22, between OH & WV, only 20 miles from the Pittsburgh Airport. Unlike other hotels, our pet-friendly hotel offers an array of complimentary amenities to guarantee a good stay, including a Fitness Center, free Wi-Fi, & an outdoor swimming pool. Join us for Breakfast & Dinner daily at Undo’s Italian Restaurant or enjoy The Sports Bar. Our guest rooms also offer free Wi-Fi, microwave & refrigerators, Keurig, flat screen TVs, ample plug outlets & a comfortable bedding package. Suites also include a kitchenette area, living rooms space, fold out sofa & a large king bedroom area. We are close to many of the area attractions such as The Pavilion at Star Lake, Mountaineer Casino, Homer Laughlin China, Steubenville Nutcracker Village & Historic Ft Steuben, Franciscan University, Steubenville OH, Tomlinson Run State Park, Raccoon State Park. Businesses in our area include Cleveland Cliffs, Cardinal Operating Plant, Form Energy, Energy Harbour Sammis Plant, Starpointe Business Park as well as oil/gas well pads in the region.

description: The Holly River Restaurant, located in Holly River State Park, has been included as one of the "101 Unique Places to Dine in West Virginia" several times. Featured menu items include homemade bread, blackberry cobbler, lasagna, rhubarb pie and roast beef sandwiches.
address: 680 State Park Road, Hacker Valley, WV 26222, USA

description: With 8,101 acres of dense forest, Holly River is West Virginia’s second largest state park. Recreational opportunities in this park include camping, hiking, swimming and tennis. Amenities include picnic shelters, the Holly River Restaurant and corrals for campers with horses. Holly River State Park’s campground has 88 units with electric hookups, picnic tables and cooking grills. A dumping station and four-centralized bathhouses are available as well as two coin-operated washers and dryers. Only one tent or trailer is allowed per site. The campground is open spring through fall, weather permitting. Campsites may be reserved anytime online, by phone, or at the campground office. Holly River State Park’s 10 cabins are the definition of cozy. Constructed of natural stone and logs, these cabins are surrounded by a dense forest of rhododendron and sturdy hemlock. These cabins are set up to accommodate either two or four people. Designated pet-friendly cabins are available. Cabins 1 through 9 are available from April through November, and Cabin 10 is available year-round. Cabins 6, 9 and 10 are pet-friendly. Check in begins at 4 p.m., and check out is by 10 a.m. for all cabins.
address: 680 State Park Road, Hacker Valley, WV 26222, USA

description: There are 25 single sites. Sites 6 -10 are reservable, but all other sites are on a first come, first serve basis. Each campsite has a parking spur, table, fire ring, tent pad, and lantern holder. Most campsites are suitable for both tent and trailer camping and can accommodate a 53 foot tow vehicle combination. Sites 9 and 10 are more wheelchair accessible than other sites. There is a large open field for horseshoe games and field sports. We have a small and a large picnic pavilion available for rental. The large electric pavilion has an occupancy limit of 75, and the small non-electric pavilion has an occupancy limit of 10. Additionally, we have drinking water, vault and flush toilets, electric and non-electric sites, as well as walk-in sites.

description: Ice Mountain gets its name from the refrigeration effect that takes place inside its talus — a sloping mass of boulders at the foot of the mountain. In cooler months, dense, cold air sinks deep into the talus, and ice masses form inside. As the weather warms up, the cooler air flows out of vents among the rocks at the bottom of the slope. The preserve protects a collection of boreal plants usually found much further north. Sustained by the cool air flowing from some 60 small holes and openings at the base of the talus, species such as twinflower, dwarf dogwood, Canada mayflower, and bristly rose all can be found here. The 149-acre preserve also provides habitat for breeding neotropical birds such as warblers, vireos and thrushes, as well as a collection of birds and animals that are typical of the Central Appalachians.

description: According to legend, "Steel-Drivin' Man" John Henry was seven feet tall and could do the work of 30 ordinary men. Henry was said to have died shortly after proving he could outwork the new steam-powered drill in cutting the Big Bend tunnel of the C&O Railroad in Talcott, West Virginia. In 1996, the U.S. Postal Service memorialized this legend by dedicating a postage stamp in his honor. A statue of Henry towers atop the mountain on Route 3 through which the railroad tunnel runs.

John Wesley Methodist Church in Lewisburg, West Virginia is a circa 1820 colonial- Greek Revival style brick church featuring a cupola belfry, high ceilings and slave galleries. Additions were made to the front in 1835. In May 1862 during the Battle of Lewisburg the John Wesley Church was struck by a cannonball fired from Confederate artillery, striking the outer wall of the church near the gallery stairs. Following the battle the church was used as a hospital treating wounded from both sides of the conflict. Today, the John Wesley Church is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and is still used as a house of worship.

description: Located on top of Rich Mountain along the western edge of the Allegheny Highlands, Kumbrabow State Forest in Randolph County is West Virginia’s highest forest. With 9,474 acres of forest at an elevation of more than 3,000 feet above sea level, Kumbrabow is used for recreation, watershed protection, commercial forestry and wildlife management. Kumbrabow State Forest features six completely furnished pioneer cabins, open from April to the first week of December. The cabins are equipped with cooking utensils, dishes, flatware, bed linens, towels and outdoor charcoal grills. Mill Creek Campground offers 13 primitive sites and one large RV site, in pristine settings, near patches of Rhododendron and a native brook trout stream. The camp sites include a fire pit and picnic tables. Firewood can be purchased at the campground or at the office. The campground is open mid-April through the first week of December. Campsites may be reserved anytime online, by phone, or at the campground office. West Virginia State Park campground reservations are available from Memorial Day through Labor Day each year. Campgrounds are open on a first-come, first-serve basis after Labor Day.

description: Site of the longest battle in the Tygart Valley Campaign. Union forces ousted the Confederate army and protected important turnpikes, securing safe passage to Wheeling for the founding fathers to plan the statehood of WV. In fleeing to Beverly, Confederate General Garnett was the first general to die in the Civil War. Annual battle reenactment is staged during the third weekend in July. The Battlefield is open to the public year-round and walking trails are marked with interpretive signage.

Tent camping, full hookup RV sites (water, sewer and electric) picnic shelters and furnished cabins are just a few of the many growing lodging options Lazy K's Campground offers. Our primitive tent camping sites are located along the beautiful Elk River. All of our RV campsites have full hook up 50 Amp electric, water and sewer. Central fresh water fill and dump stations are provided on-site for those looking for a more primitive camping experience. We have some pull through sites! Lazy K'S Campground offers year-round camping with full hook up including 30 and 50 amp RV sites. Access to the Elk river and local areas for ATV riding. Lodging includes: 3 cabins, 30 full hook up RV sites, 10-15 primitive tent sites. Lazy K's Campground and Canoe Livery is continuously growing and updating the services and amenities we offer. description: Leatherman’s Falling Waters Campsite is a 50-site RV park that has been family owned and operated since 1962. We are primarily oriented to RV travelers looking for safe, quiet place to spend the night. We are BIG-RIG friendly and have 20, 30, 50 amp power at all RV sites, as well as cable TV and free Wi-Fi. Over half of our sites have sewer hookups and are pulll-through. Tent sites are available in a shady area near a small stream. There’s a self-serve laundry on-site and climate controlled bathhouse for tent campers. In order to best accommodate our traveling customers, we offer “Call Ahead Camping” system in lieu of advance reservations. description: Dating from the 18th Century, this quaint town was the site of a Civil War battle on May 23, 1862, when Union forces attempted to sever railroad communications between Virginia and Tennessee. There is a Confederate cemetery in town, a library that was used as a hospital with Confederate graffiti on the walls, a church with a cannonball hole and a monument to the Confederate dead. The North House Museum also offers Civil War enthusiasts artifacts and documents from that era, including a packsaddle used to break Robert E. Lee’s famous horse, Traveler.

The Light Horse Inn is one of the most historic homes in Harpers Ferry. It's colorful past over the 225 year history make this home an ideal location to stay & explore the greater Harpers Ferry area. Built in the Crossroads of the Revolutionary War, the restored historic Light Horse Inn offers early American style. Seven gorgeous suites with views of mountain heights and a small town. Built circa 1770s, the Inn takes you back to a time when George Washington could have been spotted from the windows surveying the land. Complimentary breakfasts are served in the Inn's warm and inviting common rooms. The Light Horse Inn is a Revolutionary Experience!

Lily Garden Bed & Breakfast has two private suites: the Carriage House Suite and the Trundle Suite. The Trundle has a large bedroom, full bathroom and kitchenette, and is perfect for individuals and couples. Each suite has private entrances, and both offer access to our outdoor space. The shared yard includes a picnic table, covered swing, and water lily garden. Our homely amenities include a daily country breakfast, hot showers, Internet access, cable TV, and much more. Harpers Ferry is home to numerous sites of importance in American history. The area around the town includes Civil War landmarks, hiking trails, natural wonders, vineyards, biking along the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal, the Appalachian Trail and so much more.
address: 701 Washington St, Harpers Ferry, WV 25425, USA

Located in the wooded mountains of Hardy County in West Virginia’s Eastern Panhandle, Lost River State Park provides cabin lodging and an abundance of outdoor recreation. The park’s quiet 3,934 acres of woods provides a secluded getaway for nature lovers. Lost River is known for its Cranny Crow overlook on top of Big Ridge Mountain, which offers a commanding view of five counties. The park features 26 cabins (Legacy and Classic styles), hiking trails, an activity building, and outdoor swimming pool (seasonal). The abundant wildlife includes deer, bear, other woodland creatures as well as multiple songbirds and raptors. There are two primitive campsites accessible by hiking 1.5 miles on White Oak Trail to the top of Big Ridge Mountain. A public shelter, campfire ring, picnic table and latrines are on site. No potable water is available. Campsite 1 is horse friendly. Site rental is fee-based and includes firewood. Three campsites are available near the upper shelter No. 2 area of the park, close to the ball field. Sites include a fire ring, picnic table and use of the public shelter. Restrooms are located nearby, and showers are available during pool hours (seasonal). Parking is available in the ball field parking lot adjacent to the camping area. Site rental is fee-based and a reservation is required. The area can also be rented as a group camp area. Reservations are required.

description: Descend 120 feet below the Earth's surface into a vast wonderland of stalactites and stalagmites. Lost World Caverns, discovered in 1942, is a truly magical place for both young and old. It takes approximately 45 minutes to walk through. We offer self-guided tours, so you can take your time to explore the cavern at your own pace. Just remember to stay on the trail. A guide sheet is provided to tell you about the many different formations that make up this 1/2-mile loop. No matter what the temperature on the outside, the cave always remains a constant 52 degrees. A light jacket and good shoes are recommended. You'll see formations such as The Snowy Chandelier, a 30-ton compound stalactite, presumed to be one of the nation's largest. The Bridal Veil is a beautiful column of sparkling white calcite. And of course, there is the War Club, a 28-foot stalagmite made famous when Bob Addis sat on it for nearly 16 days, just to get his name in the Guinness Book of World Records. These are but a few of the formations you'll see when you visit Lost World Caverns. Bring your camera to show your friends and family the beauty of this cave when you tell them about the great time you had. Thanksgiving-March 10 a.m.-4 p.m.; April-May 9 a.m.-5 p.m.; May 15-Labor Day 9 a.m.-7 p.m.; Labor Day-Thanksgiving 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Two miles north of Lewisburg on Fairview Road (N. Court Street)
address: 907 Lost World Rd, Lewisburg, WV 24901, USA

description: The MacFarland-Hubbard House, a National Register of Historic Places property, is the third oldest house in Charleston and home of the West Virginia Humanities Council since 1999, serving WV through grants and direct programs in the humanities. The MacFarland-Hubbard House, at 1310 Kanawha Boulevard, was built in 1836 by Norris Whitteker for Isaac Noyes. The house, an example of Greek Revival architecture, was first occupied by Henry and Julia MacFarland and later occupied by the Ruby, Crowley and Hubbard families. The house took a direct hit from a cannonball during the Battle of Charleston in September 1862, and served for a time as a hospital for federal troops. Both the home and the adjacent carriage house have been restored.

description: Martinsburg’s railroading history dates back to the 1840s with the presence of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company. Engine and machine shops were used to expand the company. During the Civil War, railroads played an important part in transporting supplies and troops. On May 22, 1861, Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson’s troops halted trains traveling east at Martinsburg and Point of Rocks. Locomotives and cars, as well as tracks, bridges, telegraph wire, “Colonade” Bridge, B&O roundhouse and machine shops were destroyed. In 1866, the B&O began efforts to rebuild the roundhouse and associated machine chops for servicing locomotives. Used until the mid-1980s, the Martinsburg Roundhouse is the only cast iron-framed structure of its kind still standing today. It was also the site of the First National Labor Strike of 1877 and was a key site early during the Civil War.
address: 100 E Liberty St, Martinsburg, WV 25404, USA

The publicly owned, 295-acre Original Mason-Dixon Historical Park was established in the 1970s to commemorate the great achievement of Charles Mason and Jeremiah Dixon, the English astronomers who surveyed the Mason and Dixon Line. Brown's Hill is a National Historic Landmark and the Mason and Dixon Line is a National Civil Engineering Landmark. This location has been so honored because it was on Brown's Hill that Mason and Dixon were obliged to end their survey, 23 miles short of their goal. The Park has two pavilions, amphitheater, playground, ball courts, dining room, museum, gift shop.

company: Matewan Depot Replica Welcome Center and Museum
description: The Matewan Depot Replica Museum is a replica of the train depot that stood across the railroad tracks from downtown Matewan until the 1960s. It houses artifacts and info from the Hatfield/McCoy Feud as well as the Matewan Massacre. It also has a gift shop. Visitors can explore and experience the Matewan Depot Replica Museum at their own pace. The Depot also functions as a welcome center, so feel free to stop by and ask for tips about where to go and what to do.

The town of Matewan has a unique feature that surrounds the entire downtown area – a floodwall. The exterior of the wall tells the history of Matewan through carefully placed vertical fluting that forms an etched mural. This feature is a must-see in town. Visitors walking the path see the art on the floodwall while enjoying the Tug Fork River. The floodwall may spend the majority of its time as a piece of information art, but it also serves an important function. According to the former mayor of Matewan, Robert McCoy, the town was once described as having the most severe flooding problem in the United States. This label was well earned, as according to McCoy, by 1984, the town had faced severe, property damaging flooding in 33 of the prior 35 years. The most catastrophic floods occurred in 1957, 1963, 1977 and 1984. You can see the heights that these floods reached on the steps that lead to the river, and even as high as the floodwall. Relief came in 1992 when the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers began constructing the 2,350-foot long floodwall. Since the construction of the wall, there hasn’t been an instance of significant flooding within the downtown Matewan area.

description: In September 1777, during a Native American siege on the fort, Major Samuel McColloch arrived at the fort with 40 mounted men from Short Creek. The gates of the fort were thrown open to allow the men entrance. Major McColloch lingered behind to guide and protect the men. The Indians attacked, and all of the men except McColloch made it inside before they were forced to close the gates. McColloch found himself alone and surrounded by Native Americans, and he rode immediately towards the nearby hill in an attempt to escape. McColloch had earned a reputation as a very successful "borderer" (one who protected the frontier borders from the Native Americans) and was well known to both the frontiersmen and the Indians. The Indians eagerly pursued McColloch, and drove him to the summit of the hill. As he rode along the top of the hill, he encountered another large body of Indians. He now found himself surrounded, with no path of escape. He knew, because of his reputation and history against the Indians, he would be tortured and killed with great cruelty if he were to be captured alive. With all avenues of escape cut off, he turned and faced the precipice, and with the bridle in his left hand and his rifle in his right, he spurred his horse over the edge to an almost certain death. The hill at that location is about 300 feet in height, and in many places is almost perpendicular. The Indians rushed to the edge, expecting to see the major lying dead in a crumpled heap at the bottom of the hill. To their great surprise, they instead saw McColloch, still mounted on his white horse, galloping away from them. As legend of this famous "leap" became known, the place where it occurred became known as McColloch's Leap. A historical marker now memorializes the site of his daring feat.

You may also choose to enhance your leisure time with world-class white water rafting, golf, hiking, horseback riding, mountain biking, rock climbing, fishing and hunting, as well as a pleasant visit to several nearby West Virginia State Parks. Notably, just a short drive away is Summersville Lake, which offers Pontoon rentals; and Winterplace Ski Resort is only one hour south of Lansing. Mill Creek Cabins are located in the beautiful West Virginia mountains in the heart of the New River Gorge 1/2 mile off Rt.19, a couple miles from the New River Gorge Bridge in Lansing, WV. Entrance is located at 1163 Milroy Grose Road.

description: We are a seasonal, family campground. We have 200 tent/trailer sites, 20 RV sites, 30/50 amp electric, bath house with hot showers, handicap accessible restrooms, laundry room, camp store, public phone, fire rings and picnic tables on all reservation sites, pavilion, small playground, pebbled beach, horseshoe pits, volleyball court, basketball court, and large grassy field for other outdoor activities. Milleson's offers a variety of lots for overnight and weekend camping, as well as seasonally leased sites. Our lots are all unique in size, shape, and amenities. Our campers enjoy access to a diverse section of the South Branch of the Potomac River, and also a variety of family friendly activities throughout the entire camping season. Lease customers enjoy camping from April 15th through October 31. Reservation camping begins in May and ends September 30th. Call ahead to schedule an appointment or make a reservation. We are located off the beaten path 30 minutes North of Romney, WV; 45 minutes South of Cumberland, MD; and about 10 minutes from the small town of Springfield, WV. Our campground is situated 3 miles down a country dirt road, on a working livestock farm, along a bend in the South Branch of the Potomac River.

It was originally a produce market, however over the years it has evolved into a market of specialties. Moncove Lake State Park is tucked away among the hills on the southeastern edge of West Virginia. With all park facilities located within easy walking distance, this is the place to enjoy the simple things in life. The campground offers 48 tent and trailer sites, 34 of which have electric hookups. There are picnic tables and fire rings with grill surfaces, drinking water, dump stations and a central bathhouse with showers. Firewood is available for purchase. Three picnic shelters take reservations which can be made by calling the park office. There are also picnic areas for groups of varying sizes with grills and tables at each area and restroom facilities, water nearby, and two playground areas in the picnic area. The campground is open spring through fall, weather permitting. Campsites may be reserved anytime online, by phone, or at the campground office. The outdoor activities include camping, fishing, boating, swimming, bird watching, and hiking.

description: Information on activities at Monongahela National Forest can be found at the Supervisor’s Office at this location. Monongahela National Forest provides visitors with scenic vistas, country roads, flowing streams and abundant plant and animal life. It was established in 1920 and encompasses one of the most ecologically diverse areas in the United States. Elevations range from just under 1,000 feet to 4,863 feet above sea level. Monongahela National Forest is a working forest providing timber, water, grazing, minerals and recreational opportunities.

description: Formerly the Jerico B&B, the Moore House Inn & Cabins is nestled between two creeks and sits on six quiet acres just 1-mile from the town of Marlinton. Each private cabin has been meticulously restored with the comfort of the 21st century in mind: kitchens, plumbing, electricity and WiFi. After a day exploring Pocahontas County, take a soak under the starry sky in the hot tub, unwind in the heart-shaped jacuzzi, or curl up beside the fireplace with a captivating story. Built in 1900 by John Moore, the Inn offers guests their own private bathrooms and a daily continental breakfast. The wrap-around porch and two upstairs balconies are favorite places to relax. Guests enjoy the peaceful countryside, yet the convenience of being close to town. Motorcycle and cyclist friendly. Open year round.

description: Historic Morgan's Kitchen was built in 1846 by John Morgan Jr., who at the same time, built his first log home. Later he built a 2-story frame home. John purchased his land from George Washington's physician, James Craik. Located on MacCorkle Ave. across from Parkway Terrace, Morgan's Kitchen is typical of log structures used during its period. It was originally located at Morgan's Plantation near the present John Amos Electric Power Plant in nearby Putnam County. It was used to serve meals as well as serving as a hospital to the wounded Union soldiers during the Civil War at the battle of Scary Creek nearby. The kitchen was donated to the city of St. Albans by Sid Morgan and moved to this site in 1972, mainly by Hal Turley and his family. It is furnished with period cookware and utensils-much from the original kitchen, as well as rustic tables, a storage chest and bed.
address: 2600 MacCorkle Ave, St Albans, WV 25177, USA

description: Alumni owned and operated, the team at MBC is committed to high-quality, on-premise craft brews that satisfy the evolving tastes of todays responsible beer consumers. A Currently, the brewery offers ten of our craft brews on tap with several seasonal and small-batch special brews released every week. A MBC offers full-service dining, a large outdoor deck, and Fresh Beer for Home Use packaged in carry-out growler containers. MBC offers a unique dining and micro-brewery experience by commemorating the days of old; a time when hard work and grounded values were the norm. Pioneering settlers, coal miners, steel workers and the hands that shaped our city and state shared a philosophy of determination and quality. We commit ourselves to showcase that special piece of history in our facility, and to showcase that same determination and quality in our craft brewery, our restaurant offerings and in our service. Sunday: Brunch only 10AM-4PM Monday: CLOSED Tuesday-Friday: 4-10PM Saturday: 12-10PM Kitchen closes at 9PM every night except for Sunday when it closes at 4PM with the rest of the business.
